THE TROCHOPHORE 
i
This most ubiquitous of invertebrate larvae is characteristic of Annelius,
Molluscs, Ectoproets, Enuoproots, and Brachiepods. It is possible that the
troehophore was invented only once, but it is equally possible that it evolved
several times independently. Given the requirement of ciliary locomotion in sur-
face waters, of an alimentary system with mouth and anus, and of triploblastic
origin, then a trochophore-like organism is the simplest answer and a virtual
necessity, at least as a transient stage.
-1
,nfs
'liar.

-I 

urnThe larva carries an apical tuft of long eilia on an anterior sensory plate,
a preoral oiliated band, the prototrooh, and in many troohophores a postural
metatroch is also present, together with a telotrosh, a posterior eiliary tuft.
Internally, in addition to a oomplete alimentary canal, there is an aruhinephri-
dium, running diagonally from the mouth region to the anus region.
The trochophore arises from the gastrula by increased relative proliferation
of dorsal posterior sells (descendants of Bd), which shifts the blastophore from
the vegetative pole ventrally, to the mouth position. In some cases the blaste-
pore becomes oval, oonstriets in the middle, and so gives rise tu both mouth and
anus. Otherwise a proetodaeum breaks through independently. Alongside the in-
testine are the mesoblast cells, descendants of Ad, the larval mesoderm.
In ?npglig?, the troohophore gradually metamorohoses by posterior longitudinal
proliferation, and subsequent segmentation, of the posterior ectoderm, the meso-
blests, and the intestine, and by transformation uf the remainder of the larva into
the adult head.
In holluses, the trochophore transforms into another larva, the VELIGER, which
metamorphoses into the adult later. The Veliger is characterized principally by
three structures: the velum, a ciliated flap developed from the pretotroch and
serving as loeomotor organ; the shell gland, differentiated from the dorsal post-
prototroohal eetoaerm, which forms the mantle and shell of the adult; and the
anlage of the adult foot, originally an actodermal thickening just behind the
mouth of the troohophore, later backed increasingly by proliferating mesenehyme,
In the metamorphosing Veliger, the velu  is sloughed off and anterior larval
tissues disintegrate, Su that the mouth and the mergent foot are drawn relatively
forward, The shell by this time is typical of a given mollusean class.
